user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_close:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_close(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				struct linux_device *ldev)
{
	(void)lbus;
	unsigned int i;

	for (i = 0; i < ldev->device.num_regions; i++) {
		metal_unmap(ldev->device.regions[i].virt,
			    ldev->device.regions[i].size);
	}
	if (ldev->override) {
		sysfs_write_attribute(ldev->override, "", 1);
		ldev->override = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->sdev) {
		sysfs_close_device(ldev->sdev);
		ldev->sdev = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->fd >= 0) {
		close(ldev->fd);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_uio_dev_close:
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
...
struct linux_bus {
	struct metal_bus	bus;
	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus	*sbus;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are present in the provided code fragments. The code uses only standard C constructs: a local variable declaration, a for loop, pointer/structure member accesses, function calls, a cast to void to suppress an unused-parameter warning, and assignments. There are no GCC/Clang extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), builtins, extended designated initializers, or other compiler-specific keywords or pragmas visible in the snippets. POSIX library calls (close) and project-specific types/macros (PATH_MAX, metal_phys_addr_t, METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS) are not language extensions per the rule and therefore do not need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2. If additional source outside the shown fragments contains compiler-specific constructs, those should be reported when available.
